I've traveled to Bangladesh, Laos, India and some other 3rd world countries. They won't last a week and would turn tail to go back to clean and safe Singapore. Imagine the scarcity of clean water. It's what you learn after you know it all that counts. Ty

I think some of you are oversimplifying the situation at hand here. It’s always easy to judge the current situation and say that “we could have, would have, should have”. Like what she said, there are a lot of considerations at hand here and especially when the foreign workers’ livelihood is at stake. It is a long term issue with the poor living conditions of dormitories that is unlikely to improve in the short term. Dragging politics in here is unhelpful for any meaningful discussion as well.

She just went round and round and still did not answer the question. The question is simple, to paraphrase"what's with the delayed response wrt the dorms. Is it because of cost that you guys delay this response and not move FW earlier?"

answers.text: @lainn.e It is because of cost. Social distancing measures does not work in the dorms like they work for us. We don't stay with 11 other people in one room. FW in the dorms are the most vulnerable population when it comes to this virus. Yes some of them may  not be equipped with knowledge of the virus. However, most dorms more ill equipped with basic necessities like space  and a working toilet. The government must have known that. Aggressive testing in the dorms were only done recently as shown in our numbers. They were an after thought. Even in the media. They will report 2 numbers. One for Singapore population one for FW population as though to appease us and telling us not to worry. This shows that the yes the CB measures are working for us. But it is definitely not working for FW in the dorms. This was definitely a delayed response on our Govt's part because at that point when the 1st FW was tested positive, action should have been taken. It would have of course cost the Govt a lot to start rigorous testing and moving FW who tested positive out. But Guess what? We are still paying for it now. So yes it is about cost. Credit where credit is due. Yes our government is doing an incredible job dealing with this crisis. I'm not condemning their inaction. I'm just stating that there is a DELAYED action.

@_underarock your crux of yr argument was surrounded on the number that was squeezing in one room n their living conditions, not the idea of a permanent home. Therefore yr argument doesn’t stand. There is a reason why bmt numbers decreased and training activities have stopped bcuz it clearly can become another cluster if not taken care of. So my argument of 16 staying in one room being able to stop an outbreak holds. Therefore it’s not the number that matters but the living conditions n whether they r equipped w the knowledge to protect thenseves

@la.lala1815 n btw tekong even thou itwas my temporary home, but it’s still a place that I live in n I have the responsibility to make sure that the place is clean so that no one gets sick. If there’s no report of cases from tekong where 16 r staying in a room, why is it so that 12 fw in a room can have clusters breaking out? It’s not abt the numbers but the housing standards which yes has to be upgraded n be enforced by the Govt but first and foremost scrutiny has to be on the companies who r profit maximising n chose to cut costs in terms of living standards. N how r u sure that back in their homeland living conditions r not worse off than what they r experiencing here?
@_underarock so 16 ppl living in a room in tekong is a joke?
@lainn.e v well put 👏

@lainn.e  It's true that we have lack of space. However we are able to house people in fancy hotels during their SHN whereas FW are locked within the confines of their room of 12 people where they don't know who has the virus. FW are the building blocks of our society. And should be treated accordingly. 12 people per room is a joke. This crisis is a litmus test and it shows we are failing the FW who left their home and family. There is no need for them to invest in a flat if proper housing is provided for them. Also I would like to thank you for this enriching and healthy open discussion :))
@_underarock unverified statements but what I’m saying is the truth? Smh singaporeans like yrself r the reasons why there r websites like Singapore states times lying arnd

@_underarock honestly the ppl that are housed in hotels for SHN r at higher risk of getting covid-19 than the FWs bc they actually got in touch with many other people frm another part of the world and we don’t know as to whom they’ve ever had in contact of. Come to think of it, yes, we should spare a thought for these foreign workers but note that as much as the gvt can try their very best to treat both citizens n FWs equally well, there’ll always be one end that lose out. It’s impossible to maintain the same amount of care for both locals and FWs. That being said, i think we should be really grateful for we citizens are the ones being taken care to a greater extent of, with no delayed measures. After all, if things were otherwise and FWs were properly taken care of in priority of us, the situation in Singapore wld be much worse with many voicing out all their defences as to how they as citizens aren’t prioritised, right? Hence i feel that we shouldn’t really dwell on what the gvt did not manage to do in time but look at what has been done in preparation for the worst. At the least, our gvt is providing the subsidies and sums of money for the FWs who are to go on paid leaves.
@_underarock u clearly didn’t study economics n it shows. Brush up on yr economics instead of living under a rock
@la.lala1815 hey what's up? Why don't you come out from that fake account and produce some facts to enrich this discussion instead of trolling. Thanks 😊
@la.lala1815 dude, until you come out into the light and out of your anonymity, there is no point in discussing with you 😊
@_underarock it’s clear u r living under a rock

@_underarock well to be fair, u need to understand that sg has a lack of space. A particularly concerned factor like land, it’s scarce here. How to afford to suddenly distribute the FWs around singapore such that they have sufficient space to social distance themselves? They are already housed there all together because we do have enough facilities for them to space out because already so many areas are converted for covid-19 recovering as well as mild patients to stay. That was why when there was no need to start the dispersal of them, the gvt did not take action. Until it showed that there were clusters and the area was alr contaminated that now the gvt is stepping up its measures. Understand that from their point of view, we’re alr maxing out the areas we have for this purposes. For singaporeans however, most of us have a place/house to stay because we invested; well that doesn’t mean that FWs are being put last. It is just so that in a country like us, we have too little land for equal distribution of flats etc and do you think FWs want to invest in a house to stay at just to social distant themselves?

@_underarock hindsight is 20/20. Plus time is needed for these workers to adapt to measures such as not working n not interacting w their mates. Even us singaporeans cannot do it look at the $300 kway chap auntie, why she is unwilling to change? Bcuz habits die hard. Just in case u don’t understand economics, let me show this to u. Just like monetary policies, when implementing policies the Govt will always face 3 issues. Recognition lag implementation lag n impact lag. Recognition lag occurs because u need time to observe the problem don’t say that the Govt shld be preventing this preventing that. They r only humans not saints and which Govt would admit their mistakes openly in media? How would that look on themselves? If ppl were to make a ‘mistake’ do u think ppl would admit it immediately or would they actually try to justify their actions(which is what ppl always describe as beating arnd the bush giving politically correct answers) when all they have been doing is presenting a clear n structured argument instead of smoking the citizens? Would the opposition have been quick to admit their mistakes? Implementation lag n impact lag is self explanatory unless u r once agn living under a rock then I can explain

@_underarock it was alr mentioned its not bc of cost. it’s bc of the fact that more measures like preventing fws w their freedom of movement n interactions w their friends which require time to be implemented. think of it if u’re a fw, and the situation wasn’t as bad then, highly likely u’ll still be wanting to go to work bc u still have a family to feed and as much as u know abt this virus, alot of them are under-equipped w sufficient knowledge so it is hard for them to cooperate back then. Now, w the huge increase in cases, they’re more than convinced to follow up w these measures implemented to protect them. That’s what the minister was trying to say and it definitely addressed the qn?

They’re now suspending work in all construction companies. Foreign workers get paid by the day, and if they can’t work where is their income? Yes, we are still providing food for them. But that is just the basic necessity. They sacrifice their lives back home with their family and come here to work. But how will their family survive if the sole breadwinner effectively loses their job / income? Yes, we have Singaporeans to look after and Singaporeans should be our top priority. But for far too long, we’ve thrusted the foreign workers far from the spotlight, we’ve neglected them and lived in ignorance to their plight. They live in cramped and extremely dirty conditions, conditions we cannot even fathom. And because of this, conditions are natural for the virus to thrive. We cannot keep doing this. To neglect them. We need to do more.

@afstudio.co mere thinking is insufficient. While they may not have acted on January due to pressing bread and butter concerns, the government could have intervened to implement social distancing within dormitories. Whilst it is not possible to do so due to cramped living conditions, they can be housed in OLD CRUISE SHIPS which Singapore can and have the ability to rent/ partner. Otherwise, they can be housed in not - in- operation rental flats (Dakota, ) which have no occupants, and sufficient facilities. Locking them all up in a room at THIS POINT IN TIME is a farce. I hope my IDEAL PLANS and EXAMPLES are sufficient, pleb. To u, China may be a disproportionate comparison, but Singapore and China have comparable technology and reliant on cheap labour. In Singapore’s case- cheap labour comes from migrants, in China’s case- cheap labour is supplied from within their own country. Do note that when the lockdown in China started, they did not allow movement across the country, and it was purported that existing cheap labour are housed in FLATS that have been built (since SARS as China has prepared for this). Did Singapore have a contingency plan? So.. just because there are limitations, the government concedes and decides to let the numbers grow exponentially? Should we allow the cases within the migrant’s group to hit 200,000?

@afstudio.co For a start, I would have strictly enforced the measures that were implemented early on the dormitories in January (according to our dear Josephine), making sure these measures were adhered to by sending official manpower to check and not having to depend on company/operators. If you want something done, best do it yourself or with your own people. But that's just me, I guess our politicians had better plans since they're paid hundreds of thousands to think and run things things 🤷🏻‍♂️

@7uns they do not have enough manpower rn to handle the situation.. a lot of the medical staff going down to dormitories are VOLUNTEERS (eg retired doctors) your statement literally shows how shallow your understanding of the current situation actually is..

@precious_moment2 oh so let say u were her, and seeing this current situation, are u going to daring say that u won’t have a bit of panic/nervousness answering the question while at the same time handling the problem?
@7uns I'm curious as to what you are expecting the govt to do in the first place to stop the spike in cases for foreign workers?

@solosubwaymuncher You're not exactly wrong. But initial question was "What went wrong with the dormitories?" Cost was just a factor that might or might not have been. So if she had answered straight to the point like you said, she could have just told the interviewer of what went wrong instead of beating around the bush.

@afstudio.co So what you're saying is, MOM does not have the manpower luxuries then but they have it now after the dormitory spikes to move the workers in a large scale and do whatever necessary measures they're doing now? Cool okay.
@11giraffes Erm what?? What has this got to do with not receiving income? Don't sidetrack please.

@dekohlourised Err no one's saying anything about there not being a need to act on foresight. Obviously empathy and consideration is warranted for them during this time, not just because there's a spike in cases but simply because they're valued individuals. But the problem here is foresight is not always right or accurate, and who are we to say that we would have known better? I am not even saying that the government is doing the right thing, what I am saying is it's very easy to point fingers and push the blame when we ourselves don't know better. There are probably many other things that individuals don't have to consider when we perceive the situation on hand because we are not accountable for anyone but ourselves but it's not the same when it comes to companies and organisations.

@7uns even until now MOM still relies om these dorm operators to enfore the measures. In the first place they have been becoming "the ambassador" to ensure the measure is taken seriously. Thats all i can say.
@7uns Ok then you try to not receive income for half a year without complaining ya
@7uns she seemed very nervous when presenting her speech. All eyes were on her to see how is she going to answer for the mishandling.
@7uns how do you know that she was lying about implementing measures in foreign dormitories in January or not?

@afstudio.co @7runs the ambassadors that you perhaps seen at public places right now may not be MOM employees, fyi. They are a group of public servants and volunteers. So, all of us staying in singapore have to take part in this to fight back the virus. Not to play a blaming game. Let's support our government with the best effort we can do or at least pray for them. Stay safe and healthy. Take care.

@7uns to be fair, the question was targeted on the concept of hight cost, (but it was fabricated in a way to not make it seem like the governments are kiasu with money when it comes to treating foreigners) and I think that the minister went straight to the point
@pschonacho I’m championing for social distancing at public spaces and in dorms, HAve I mentioned not working?

@afstudio.co of course we have insights for the government. In our nanny state, we have no choice and no voice, there isn’t conversations about migrants, NOTHING. In this questioning, Josephine responded that they have “educated” the workers, but they chose not to do anything beyond because its “unreasonable”. HOWEVER, social distancing measures were not implemented at the earlier stages- the workers are still packed like sardines in each dormitory. Is it not common sensical that transmission will be prevalent especially in dorms? The key question is WHY WERE THEY NOT SEGREGATED PROPERLY. It stems from systemic ignorance from our government- failing to acknowledge the severity of the issue, failing to implement proper social distancing from the beginning AT A STATE LEVEL. well, u can argue that nobody thought covid-19 would be transmitted around the dorms, but as the ministry of manpower , it is essential to have foresight and have adequate preparation in the event it happens. Time and time again we are taught “not what if, but WHEN” - well INSUFFICIENT measures were implemented. parallel to CHINA, they have done vigorous social distancing for all workers who reside in dorms, ever since sars, they built spare apartments in the event a virus outbreak occurs. Although we have lack of land, we surely can utilise on our existing facilities. As a “first world country”, we can do more. And stop being so ignorant of these issues and start being critical

text: She's already answered it herself, if it's not about the cost then why are they so many foreign workers here in the first place?

answers.text: @aviation_geek yes, but why? I'm quite sure many of us know the reason but we choose to ignore it until the day it comes to bite us.

@venus.txy absolutely not discrediting the important work that migrant workers do in Singapore, however, it is important to think about why the singaporean society is so dependent on migrant workers. The answer is always Singaporean’s aren’t willing to do it because it’s tough blue collar work and we are too privileged to do so. But if that’s the case, why have other first world countries like Scandinavian states and Australia been able to have local workers doing blue collar work (like sanitation and construction) but we haven’t in Singapore? Perhaps the wage structure for blue collar work in Singapore has to change. Migrant workers earn low wages in Singapore, but the exchange rates make it feasible for them to make a living in Singapore and send money home. It is extremely difficult for a Singaporean to earn the current blue collar wages and make a living and feed a family in Singapore

@kid474 yes I definitely agreed with his respond that Singaporeans are definitely way too privileged to pick up such blue collar work but that doesn’t mean that your initial comment that it’s “just about cost” is correct because it ultimately boils down to supply and demand. There happen to be a supply of such foreign workers at that given price point in which Singapore is offering. Cost would just become a secondary benefit to the govt and to MOM. Do you think that if suddenly all borders were closed and we CANT hire foreign workers, the govt would just be like “fuck it guess we can’t have anymore labour intensive jobs in singapore”? Obv not, but that’s just how society grows as a whole, through specialisation where people do the jobs in which they are skilled at to increase efficiency as a whole
@venus.txy well, you've have the answer. 😉
@venus.txy I believe the person above has already answered your question, and have you asked yourself the same question?
@kid474 yeah that ur using a bs excuse to try and reason something lmfao
@aviation_geek can*
@kid474 not many locals would want to do some jobs here.
@kid474 Yep. Whatever the reason is, hope this is over and we learn our lesson. Our voices and views and be expressed at the ballot box later this year.

@kid474 are u being serious? obviously dormitories are being built based on the expected no. of migrant workers the company is planned on hiring. Obviously i don’t deny that it’s has now become a norm for companies to hire foreign workers whenever they can because which company would want to lose out? but if it was all about cost why are there mandatory quotas stating the limit and percentage of foreign workers a company can have?
@venus.txy I couldn't take the 'happen to be a supply of such foreign workers'.. the dormitories were there already in the first place? It was all in the plan.
@kid474 if the govt ask u or your children to do the work they did, would you be willing to?
@kid474 what a stupid qn lol
@venus.txy there is nothing bad in what they doing its working. if the pay is good and can survive living in Singapore. Many will do it... 2.50$ per hour err currently..

@la.lala1815 ya i know the reason why it's called cb duh. but almost everyone knows that this cb is a partial lockdown. honestly i feel like it just embarrassed them when they said we are never going into lockdown then look at us. we are almost doing everything similar to lockdown but the term itself.

@la.lala1815 the government has the ultimate jurisdiction over the dorm operators. but the situation was neglected until it couldn't be ignored any further when the issue of overcrowding in dorms was brought up very early on into the outbreak and was a ticking timebomb waiting to explode. you think dorm operators care about the government "advisories" meh? it was physically impossible to maintain social distancing with the level of overcrowding in those dorms. and besides, the lockdown imposed on the dorms was mandated OVERNIGHT. she talk so much about giving them time, slowly easing them into it, when all it did was spread the virus further to even more people. it was a huge oversight on their part and she's just trying to cover her own ass and you're falling for it.
